intro: Roldana petasitis var. cristobalensis, commonly known as the Cristobalensis Roldana, is a rare and unique plant species native to specific regions of Central America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton plants, and is characterized by its distinctive floral structures. The plant typically grows in humid, shaded environments, often in tropical or subtropical forests. Its leaves are palmate, with broad, lobed shapes, and it produces showy, trumpet-shaped flowers in shades of yellow and orange. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species facing threats from deforestation and habitat loss.
